v.v: Can you draw out Leviathan with a fishhook?
Can you put a rope into his nose,
Will he make many pleas to you?
Will he make a covenant with you,
Will you play with him as you would with a bird?
Will the groups of fishermen bargain for him?
Can you fill his hide with harpoons
Put your hand on him just once,
See, the hope of anyone who does that is a lie;

v: Or tie up his jaws with a cord?
or pierce his jaw through with a hook?
Will he speak soft words to you?
that you should take him for a servant forever?
Will you tie him up for your servant girls?
Will they divide him up to trade among the merchants?
or his head with fishing spears?
and you will remember the battle and do it no more.
will not anyone be thrown down to the ground just by the sight of him?

v.v: None is so fierce that he dare stir Leviathan up;
Who has first given anything to me in order that I should repay him?

v: who, then, is he who can stand before me?
Whatever is under the whole sky is mine.

v.v: I will not keep silent concerning Leviathan’s legs,
Who can strip off his outer covering?
Who can open the doors of his face—
his back is made up of rows of shields,

v: nor about the matter of his strength, nor about his graceful form.
Who can penetrate his double armor?
ringed with his teeth, which are a terror?
tight together as with a close seal.

v.v: One is so near to another
They are joined to each other;
Light flashes out from his snorting;
Out of his mouth go burning torches,
Out of his nostrils goes smoke
His breath kindles coals into flame;
In his neck is strength,
The folds of his flesh are joined together;
His heart is as hard as a stone—
When he raises himself up, even the gods become afraid;
If a sword strikes him, it does nothing—
He thinks of iron as if it were straw,
An arrow cannot make him flee;
Clubs are regarded as straw;
His lower parts are like sharp pieces of broken pottery;
He makes the deep to foam up like a pot of boiling water;
He makes a shining wake behind him;
On earth there is no equal to him,
He sees everything that is proud;

v: that no air can come between them.
they stick together, so that they cannot be pulled apart.
his eyes are like the eyelids of the morning dawn.
sparks of fire leap out.
like a boiling pot on a fire that has been fanned to be very hot.
fires go out from his mouth.
and terror dances in front of him.
they are firm on him; they cannot be moved.
indeed, as hard as a lower millstone.
because of fear, they draw back.
and neither does a spear, an arrow, or any other pointed weapon.
and of bronze as if it were rotten wood.
to him sling stones become chaff.
he laughs at the whirring flight of a spear.
he leaves a spreading trail in the mud as if he were a threshing sledge.
he makes the sea like a pot of ointment.
one would think the deep had gray hair.
who has been made to live without fear.
he is king over all the sons of pride.”
